document.title: Front Desk Manager Manual
document.description: Comprehensive front desk manager manual with procedures, protocols, and guidelines for daily operations.

sections.title: Introduction to the FD Manager Role
sections.content:
As the Guest Services Manager at J. Joseph Salon, you play a vital role in the success and day-to-day operations of the company. You are the bridge between guests, your team, and leadership. This manual exists to give you clear, actionable guidance to help you succeed and grow in this role.

Your core purpose is to foster a welcoming, efficient, and elevated front desk experience while supporting the goals of the salon and leading your team with clarity and consistency.

You'll collaborate with the Salon Manager and Assistant Manager (if applicable) to help guide the growth and culture of your location. You're also expected to:

  • Maintain and enhance customer satisfaction
  • Train, support, and grow the FD team
  • Support recruiting efforts
  • Help uphold high cleanliness and operational standards
  • Use social media to support JJS brand growth and visibility

All policies and expectations listed in this manual are reviewed and updated at the end of each year. As a leader, your role is dynamic — your growth, communication, and performance have a direct impact on the salon, your team, and your own career path.

Welcome to the FD Manager Manual. Let's raise the standard, lead by example, and elevate the guest experience together.

sections.title: Key Responsibilities of an FD Manager
sections.content:
Core Responsibilities

Use this list to guide your weekly focus and performance reviews.

  • Enhance Customer Satisfaction
    Implement and refine customer service strategies to increase satisfaction scores.
  • Team Growth & Hiring
    Identify when new hires are needed and support their onboarding and training.
  • Clear Communication
    Keep open, ongoing communication with the Salon Manager and your team.
  • Sales Promotion
    Encourage sales of retail products and services with engaging front desk scripts.
  • Team Morale
    Celebrate wins, create a positive culture, and encourage peer accountability.
  • Auditing & Quality Control
    Conduct weekly audits and quarterly performance reviews for your FD team.
  • Goal Setting & Tracking
    Work with each team member to set measurable goals (sales, reviews, attendance).
  • Scheduling Oversight
    Ensure all shifts are fairly scheduled and properly covered across all locations.
  • Cleanliness & Organization
    Keep your desk, drawers, folders, and lobby area clean, neat, and guest-ready.
  • Work History & Documentation
    Record callouts, warnings, and positive performance in the Monday.com board.

This list is not just a checklist — it's your framework for leadership. Own it with consistency, empathy, and clear communication.

sections.title: FD Scheduling & Shift Oversight
sections.content:
Scheduling is one of the most crucial responsibilities of an FD Manager. Your goal is to create fair, efficient, and balanced coverage while avoiding burnout and confusion.

📆 Scheduling Guidelines

  • Create monthly schedules in the "When I Work" app.
  • Publish schedules mid-month to allow for time-off requests and reviews.
  • Your own hours should be consistent week-to-week.
  • Ensure balanced ON-CALL shifts, especially on weekends.
  • No FD employee (at any level) is allowed to go into overtime without approval.
  • Alternating AM/PM shifts on Fridays & Saturdays is required.

📌 Required Presence

Monday: Mandatory office/admin day

  • Check supplies
  • Confirm schedules
  • Review Sunday performance
  • Plan the week
  • Cannot be missed without prior approval

Friday & Saturday:

  • Must alternate opening and closing with your team

Sunday:

  • Recommended day off to reset and avoid burnout

📈 Shift Audits & Adjustments

  • Quarterly: Audit FD hours to ensure everyone is meeting their expectations
  • If someone isn't meeting scheduled hours or skips Sundays/Mondays:
    • Flag it
    • Notify the Salon Manager
    • Suggest coverage solutions

🚨 Call-Out Policy

  • All call-outs must be documented in Monday.com under Work History
  • FD Manager must:
    • Find coverage OR
    • Personally fill in
  • Communicate all repeat or suspicious patterns to the Salon Manager and GM

Proper scheduling ensures fairness, accountability, and a fully functioning guest experience at all times.

sections.title: FD Team Training & Development Standards
sections.content:
As an FD Manager, your team's performance and growth are a reflection of your leadership. Training isn't one-and-done — it's continuous, clear, and personalized.

Use this article as a guide for building a confident, consistent, and capable Front Desk team.

🚀 Onboarding & Orientation

  • Conduct a complete walk-through of salon systems, tools, and policies.
  • Use the official Orientation Checklist and Key Holder Agreement.
  • Ensure all new hires have reviewed:
    • Service categories
    • Pricing structure
    • Desk procedures
    • Policies on call-outs, cleanliness, and phones
  • Explain the purpose of the Drive Folder and how to access all current documentation.

📅 Performance Development Meetings (PDMs)

  • Schedule monthly 1-on-1 meetings with each FD team member.
  • Discuss:
    • Personal goals
    • Progress on KPIs (retail, prebooks, reviews)
    • Areas for improvement
    • Any challenges they're facing
  • Keep notes and submit feedback to the General Guest Services Manager.

🎓 Ongoing Training

  • Reinforce scripts, tone, and guest service expectations weekly.
  • Lead by example — your daily behavior trains them more than words.
  • Assign training tasks when repeated mistakes or knowledge gaps appear.

💡 Cross-Training & Versatility

  • Encourage team members to rotate between:
    • Reception
    • Retail sales
    • Inventory support
  • This flexibility builds confidence and improves schedule coverage.

📦 Product Knowledge & Retail Goals

  • Train the team on how to confidently talk about products.
  • Coordinate with the Inventory Manager to assign retail sales goals.
  • Offer mini bonuses, incentives, or recognition when goals are hit.

🌟 Recognition & Motivation

  • Celebrate achievements in Slack, at team meetings, or via 1:1 shout-outs.
  • Submit recommendations for promotions or level increases to leadership.
  • Make growth feel visible and achievable for every FD team member.

You're not just managing a desk — you're building future leaders. Own the role of coach and mentor daily.

sections.title: How to Handle Unhappy Guests – 12-Step Protocol
sections.content:
Handling unhappy guests is one of your most sensitive and impactful responsibilities. By following a consistent, empathetic approach, you can often turn a negative moment into a loyal return visit.

Use this 12-step protocol to coach yourself and your team.

🧭 12-Step Protocol for Guest Complaints

  1. Active Listening
    Greet the guest warmly. Make eye contact. Let them explain their issue without interrupting.
  2. Stay Calm & Composed
    Your tone, body language, and patience set the emotional tone. Stay professional, even if the guest is upset.
  3. Acknowledge & Apologize
    "I'm truly sorry to hear that. Let's see how we can make this right."
  4. Ask Clarifying Questions
    Dig deeper without blaming:
    "Can you walk me through what happened?"
  5. Offer Solutions
    Recommend realistic, policy-aligned options that meet the guest's needs.
  6. Involve the Right People
    If it involves a stylist or service concern, involve the Salon Manager or appropriate team member.
  7. Document the Issue
    Log the situation in your designated place (ticket system, Monday.com, or internal form).
  8. Follow Up
    If unresolved on-site, follow up via email or phone within 24–48 hours with a solution or update.
  9. Spot Recurring Patterns
    If similar issues repeat, log them for management. It may indicate a process or training issue.
  10. Train the Team
    Make this 12-step process part of onboarding and retraining.
  11. Escalate When Needed
    Some guests may require GM or HR involvement — never guess, always escalate if unsure.
  12. Close the Loop
    If resolved, thank the guest for their feedback and confirm they're satisfied.

💬 Pro Tip:

Less talking, more listening. Most guests want to feel heard and understood before anything else.

This approach builds trust, protects the salon's reputation, and empowers you and your team to lead with confidence.

sections.title: Front Desk Operations & Inventory Management
sections.content:
As the FD Manager, you are responsible for the efficiency, cleanliness, and readiness of the front desk. In addition, you manage supply inventory and communication with the Inventory Specialist.

🛎️ Daily Operational Duties

  • Keep the front desk and lobby neat, professional, and guest-ready.
  • Check drawers, folders, printer, and all surfaces for organization.
  • Maintain a food-free zone to prevent bugs and uphold presentation.
  • Ensure the desk is stocked with pens, business cards, gift cards, and sign-in tools.
  • Monitor the coffee area for cleanliness and supplies.

📨 Communication & Logs

  • Process all emails, Slack messages, and task requests promptly.
  • Check and respond to any unresolved issues from the day prior.
  • Ensure daily duties (AM/PM) are being filled out by team members.
  • Reply to end-of-day emails and resolve or escalate issues as needed.

📦 Supply & Inventory Oversight

  • Oversee all FD supply orders.
  • Keep inventory organized and accessible — no hoarding or understocking.
  • Report low supply alerts to the Inventory Specialist immediately.
  • Confirm deliveries and ensure paperwork is scanned or filed properly.

🧾 Order Receiving & Check-In

  • Train your team to follow the official FD order checking process.
  • Review accuracy of every shipment received.
  • Communicate back to Inventory Manager if there are discrepancies.

🛍️ Retail Display Management

  • Prioritize display space for new launches and JJS-branded products.
  • Rotate signage and check for outdated promos or empty spots.
  • Post promo signs and coupon codes as directed by the Inventory Manager.

📊 Inventory Audits

  • Conduct quarterly counts in coordination with the Inventory Specialist.
  • Ensure logs are updated and discrepancies are flagged immediately.
  • Keep communication open and proactive to avoid last-minute stock issues.

When operations and inventory are well-managed, your entire team performs better — and guests feel the difference immediately.

sections.title: Service Adjustments & Escalation Process
sections.content:
At J. Joseph Salon, we recognize that even with high standards, service adjustments may be needed. As the FD Manager, it's your responsibility to ensure these situations are handled with professionalism, empathy, and consistency — whether or not the guest is "right."

🛠️ Daily Calendar Review

  • Review the day's calendar each morning for any scheduled service adjustments.
  • Highlight them so you or your team can be prepared to greet the guest with care.

👋 Greeting Guests with Adjustments

When the guest arrives:

  • Welcome them with warmth and empathy.
  • Acknowledge their reason for being there — be calm and professional.
  • Let them know we're here to make things right and restore their confidence.

📣 Team Training & Coverage

  • Train FD staff on how to handle service adjustment visits when you are not present.
  • Designate a team lead or experienced FD member to oversee the guest's visit.
  • Set expectations: calm tone, listen, avoid excuses, and follow policy.

⚙️ Processing Adjustments

  • All adjustments must follow established salon procedures.
  • Apply the correct adjustment code in the system (based on policy).
  • Never issue refunds or compensation outside your authority.
  • Document everything:
    • Guest's name
    • Adjustment made
    • Who processed it
    • Any stylist/staff notes
    • Screenshots or photos if applicable

📈 Escalation Steps

If a guest is not satisfied or requests more than the policy allows:

  1. Let them know you'll be escalating their concern.
  2. Notify the Salon Manager immediately and provide full context.
  3. Document and alert HR if it's a pattern or a sensitive case.
  4. Give the guest a clear follow-up window:
    "Our Salon Manager will follow up with you by [day/time]."

📌 Ongoing Monitoring

  • Audit your team's consistency in handling adjustments.
  • Share feedback or repeated patterns with the General Manager.

Handled well, service adjustments can turn negative moments into loyalty wins — but only with clear process and follow-through.

sections.title: Cleanliness & Space Standards for the FD Team
sections.content:
Cleanliness is part of the guest experience. As FD Manager, it's your responsibility to hold the team to high standards of cleanliness, organization, and visual presentation — at all times.

🧼 Daily Pre-Shift Audit

Before each shift begins, the front desk should be:

  • Fully stocked (pens, gift cards, sign-in sheets, promo cards, etc.)
  • Completely free of food or drink (except water in sealed containers)
  • Trash removed
  • Surfaces sanitized (including keyboard, monitor, phone, and counter)
  • Drawers neat and labeled
  • Front desk rug vacuumed or shaken if applicable

☕ Coffee Area Maintenance

  • Keep the area stocked, wiped, and organized.
  • Ensure no overflow trash, open food, or spills.
  • Cups, lids, stirrers, and sugars should be tidy and refillable by guests.

🪑 Lobby Cleanliness & Deep Cleaning

  • Lobby chairs arranged neatly
  • Hair swept or vacuumed from floors
  • Dust-free furniture and product displays
  • Perform a weekly deep clean of the entire lobby and front desk area

🚻 Restroom Standards

FD Managers are responsible for regular restroom checks:

  • Start of shift
  • Midway through shift
  • End of shift

Check for:

  • Toilet paper, paper towels, soap
  • Clean counters and mirrors
  • No overflowing trash

📋 Shift Start Audit

Audit that all AM/PM cleaning and setup duties are being completed.
If skipped or done poorly, address it in real-time and retrain if needed.

🔁 Team Accountability

  • FD team should be reminded weekly:
    "The guest's first impression is the front desk and lobby."
  • Set expectations clearly and lead by example.
  • Cleanliness standards are a reflection of our brand.

By maintaining these standards, you ensure every guest and team member experiences a professional, polished, and welcoming environment — from the moment they walk in.

sections.title: Scheduling Policies – Time Off, Call-Outs & On-Call Coverage
sections.content:
The FD Manager ensures consistent coverage — even when team members are unavailable. These scheduling and attendance policies are non-negotiable to keep the salon running smoothly.

📝 Time-Off Requests

  • All requests must be submitted via the scheduling app (When I Work) with adequate notice.
  • Approve based on:
    • Existing coverage
    • Holiday weeks
    • Pattern of absences
  • Mondays off require prior approval — they are considered an office/admin day.

🚨 Call-Out Protocol

  • All call-outs must be reported via phone, not just text or Slack.
  • FD Manager must:
    • Log the call-out reason in Monday.com → Work History
    • Attempt to find same-day coverage
    • Step in if no one is available (especially weekends or peak hours)
  • Patterned or excessive call-outs must be escalated to the General Manager and documented.

📱 On-Call Shifts

  • All weekend shifts must include an on-call team member in case of emergencies.
  • Team members who agree to same-day coverage or on-call activation are eligible for:
    • 1.5x hourly rate for that shift
    • Must be approved and logged with GM and Payroll

📆 Schedule Monitoring

  • Review weekly and monthly for:
    • Frequent absences
    • Weekend or Monday gaps
    • Missed peak hour coverage
  • Report repeat gaps to the Salon Manager with recommendations.

These policies ensure fairness, prevent burnout, and protect team accountability.

sections.title: Weekly & Monthly FD Manager Audits
sections.content:
FD Managers are expected to proactively audit their front desk operations to maintain quality, accountability, and consistency. These audits ensure everything is running smoothly — even when leadership isn't present.

📅 Weekly Audit Responsibilities

Every week, you should:

  • Review morning and evening duty logs
    • Confirm they're being filled out with accurate, detailed feedback
  • Check for any unresolved notes in:
    • End-of-day emails
    • Slack messages
    • Duty forms
  • Review supply levels and ensure no last-minute shortages
  • Monitor daily attendance patterns for the FD team
  • Confirm coffee, restroom, and retail areas meet cleanliness standards

🧾 Monthly Audit Checklist

Once a month, you must perform a full FD location audit and report findings to your Salon Manager.

Your checklist includes:

  • ✅ Dress code compliance (including hair/makeup)
  • ✅ Desk appearance (neat, branded, clean, stocked)
  • ✅ Inventory reports submitted and aligned with reality
  • ✅ Cancellation lists posted and reviewed
  • ✅ Daily close-out emails logged and replied to
  • ✅ Sunday & holiday coverage confirmed
  • ✅ "Redo paperwork" filed and up to date (for service adjustments)
  • ✅ Monthly FD goals reviewed and tracked
  • ✅ Guest follow-up logs maintained
  • ✅ Opening/closing checklist followed
  • ✅ Phone call audits reviewed from GSOM or upper management

📤 Reporting Protocol

  • Submit audit summaries to your Salon Manager.
  • Escalate any inconsistencies, team issues, or missed expectations immediately.
  • Missed audits or skipped reviews reflect directly on your leadership.

These audits aren't about micromanagement — they're about raising the standard and holding your location accountable to the guest experience.

sections.title: Coverage Policy
sections.content:
As the FD Manager, it is your responsibility to ensure the front desk is covered at all times — no exceptions. This includes last-minute gaps, vacations, call-outs, and high-traffic events.

👤 Manager Coverage Responsibility

  • If an FD team member does not show up, the FD Manager must:
    • Immediately begin calling other FD team members for backup
    • If no one can cover, the FD Manager must step in personally
  • This applies to:
    • Weekends
    • Peak hours
    • Holidays
    • Last-minute call-outs

📲 On-Call & Emergency Coverage

  • Ensure the "When I Work" app is updated with on-call staff each weekend
  • On-call staff should be notified in advance and confirm they are available
  • If an on-call employee is activated same-day:
    • Notify the GM via email for 1.5x pay approval
    • Log the reason and who filled the shift

🌴 Vacation Coverage

  • If you (the FD Manager) are on vacation:
    • You must arrange FD coverage in advance
    • Notify the Guest Services Manager and Salon Manager
    • Share emergency contact info in case coverage fails
    • Stay available for urgent support unless otherwise approved

🔁 Policy Reminders

  • A missed shift without coverage = manager accountability
  • It is never acceptable for the front desk to be left unattended
  • Rely on your team, backups, and on-call structure — but be ready to lead when needed

Coverage is not just a task — it's a core leadership function that protects the salon experience and operational flow.

sections.title: FD Manager Expectations (Punctuality, Dress Code & Attitude)
sections.content:
As a leader, your presence sets the tone for the entire front desk team — even when you're not speaking. Every detail matters: how you show up, what you wear, and how you carry yourself directly impacts culture, trust, and respect.

⏰ Punctuality & Preparedness

  • Arrive early, not on time — be ready to work before your scheduled shift
  • Check that all systems, supplies, and team members are ready to go
  • Maintain a full-time schedule unless otherwise approved
  • Office hours (1 hour/week) must be used for:
    • Reviewing team progress
    • Candidate phone screenings
    • Admin duties or audits

🎽 Dress Code & Grooming

FD Managers are expected to follow and model the salon's official appearance policy:

  • Hair styled and clean
  • Full makeup or clean natural grooming
  • No hoodies, casual loungewear, or dirty shoes
  • Business casual with trend-forward or polished presentation

You represent leadership at the front desk. Your appearance should reflect the standard you want your team to follow.

🧠 Attitude & Behavior

  • Maintain a professional, positive, and solution-driven attitude
  • Do not bring personal frustrations into the workspace
  • Model emotional control and resilience during peak stress times
  • If team conflict arises, address it privately and tactfully

📢 Lead By Example

Your tone, timing, and attention to detail are teaching your team how to behave — whether you realize it or not. Lead with confidence, consistency, and humility.

The FD Manager isn't just a schedule or a shift — it's a standard.

sections.title: Supply Orders & Holiday Inventory Management
sections.content:
Managing supplies is more than just reordering pens — it's about keeping operations seamless and guest-facing areas stocked, clean, and branded, especially during busy seasons like the holidays.

📦 Daily & Weekly Supply Oversight

  • Check all FD supplies at the start of your Monday office hours
  • Inventory should include:
    • Sign-in sheets
    • Business cards
    • Gift cards
    • Pens, printer paper
    • Receipt paper
    • Appointment cards
    • Guest incentive materials (when applicable)
  • If any supplies are low:
    • Submit an order to the Inventory Specialist that day
    • Track ETA and confirm delivery
    • Store restocked items properly (no clutter or overstocking)

🗂️ Supply Communication Protocol

  • Log all requests and confirmations via Slack or internal email
  • Ensure all paperwork, invoices, and tracking slips are:
    • Saved in your location's shared drive or binder
    • Forwarded to the Inventory Manager if needed

🎄 Holiday Preparation

  • Review calendar in October for:
    • Gift card promo signage
    • Holiday retail displays
    • Supply needs (extra gift cards, tissue, branded packaging)
  • Submit bulk orders no later than November 1st
  • Ensure signage around salon is clear:
    • "We offer holiday gift cards for your convenience."
    • "Ask us about our seasonal retail bundles."

🏆 Gift Card Contest Supplies

  • Ensure your location has a $100 gift card set aside (provided by corporate)
  • Track FD team member sales from November through New Year
  • Announce winner during January's beginning-of-year meeting

When managed well, inventory and holiday readiness improve both sales and guest satisfaction — without unnecessary stress.

sections.title: Social Media & Recruiting Guidelines for the FD Team
sections.content:
Social media is part of your job as an FD Manager. It supports both internal recruiting and public-facing brand awareness. Your personal and team posts should reflect professionalism, positivity, and alignment with J. Joseph Salon's values.

📲 FD Manager Expectations on Social Media

  • Maintain a clean and professional personal profile
  • Represent JJS with pride — avoid drama, gossip, or controversial topics
  • Promote open positions when asked (FD, stylist, apprentice, etc.)
  • Share only approved graphics or brand-aligned imagery
  • Never post pricing, confidential guest info, or screenshots of internal systems

🔍 Supporting Recruiting Efforts

You may occasionally be asked to help promote hiring campaigns.

  • Share job postings from the official JJS accounts or recruitment team
  • Use approved captions or hashtags
  • Tag the appropriate salon location
  • Respond professionally if anyone comments asking about roles:
    • "We're currently accepting applications! You can apply directly at jjosephsalon.com/careers."

📸 Guest & Team Content Rules

  • Never post guest photos without written consent
  • All new hire announcements or team promotions should be shared through Slack or internal email before posting
  • Do not post sensitive internal info (schedules, complaints, numbers)

🚫 What Not to Do

  • Complain about coworkers, managers, or guests
  • Post behind-the-scenes "rant" content, even in stories
  • Share screenshots of internal systems like "When I Work" or Monday.com
  • Engage in stylist drama or conflict via public posts

✅ Best Practices

  • Celebrate wins (new hire, reviews, awards)
  • Use clean, high-quality images
  • Tag @jjosephsalon when sharing any business-related post
  • Encourage your team to grow their professional presence too

Social media is one of your most powerful tools — when used right. You're not just representing yourself — you're representing the brand.

sections.title: Orientation & Shadowing Process for New Hires
sections.content:
FD Managers are responsible for ensuring all new hires feel welcomed, trained, and confident before taking solo shifts. Orientation is not just a walkthrough — it's a hands-on process that builds knowledge, trust, and culture from day one.

📝 Day 1 Orientation Overview

  • Welcome the new hire and walk them through:
    • Salon layout & departments
    • Key FD duties and expectations
    • Our brand's tone, values, and culture
  • Review:
    • Call-out policy
    • Dress code
    • Cleanliness standards
    • Customer service expectations
  • Provide a copy of:
    • FD Duty Checklist
    • Orientation Packet
    • Key Holder Agreement

👥 Shadowing Schedule

  • Assign shadow shifts over the new hire's first 1–2 weeks
  • Shadowing should rotate across:
    • Opening shift (AM duties)
    • Closing shift (PM duties)
    • Peak time shift (weekends or evenings)
  • Each shift must include:
    • Hands-on learning
    • Observation
    • Task assignments with real responsibility

📋 Evaluation & Sign-Off

  • Before allowing a solo shift:
    • Evaluate the new hire using a checklist or quick evaluation form
    • Confirm they understand:
      • Phone scripts
      • Booking systems
      • Retail areas
      • Guest greetings & check-out process
  • Have them sign the Key Holder Agreement
  • Submit a summary to the Salon Manager

💬 Feedback Loop

  • Ask for feedback from the new hire and their shadowing mentors
  • Identify gaps or areas needing extra review
  • Schedule follow-ups if confidence or consistency is lacking

Successful onboarding creates confident, empowered employees — and protects the guest experience from day one.

sections.title: Annual Responsibilities & Year-End Reports
sections.content:
At the close of each year, FD Managers must complete a series of reviews, reports, and cleanups to ensure the front desk is fully reset and ready for the new year. This process helps the leadership team plan effectively and recognize team progress.

📆 Due Date

All annual responsibilities must be completed and submitted by December 30 unless directed otherwise by upper management.

📋 Required End-of-Year Tasks

  • Complete a full FD team review including:
    • Strengths
    • Areas for improvement
    • Promotion recommendations
    • Repeat policy violations (if any)
  • Submit a written review of your own performance as FD Manager:
    • What you're proud of
    • What you learned
    • Goals for next year
  • Clean out:
    • All drawers and cabinets
    • Physical files and unnecessary printouts
    • Unused supplies or expired paperwork
  • Update and upload:
    • Most recent FD Duty Checklist
    • Any training forms or updated procedures
    • Your FD team's current schedule and phone list
  • Inventory:
    • Pens, gift cards, appointment cards, etc.
    • Submit order requests for January (if needed)

📊 Reporting to Leadership

  • Submit all completed reviews to:
    • Your Salon Manager
    • The General Guest Services Manager
  • Be prepared to review them during your annual FD Manager check-in

🧹 Deep Clean Expectations

  • Final week of December:
    • Wipe all tech and surfaces
    • Disinfect common areas
    • Reset desk for January 1 launch
    • Confirm all holiday signage is removed

💡 Purpose

This process helps set the tone for the new year, reinforces accountability, and gives your leadership team visibility into your team's performance and needs.

sections.title: Scripts & Guest Verbiage Reference Guide
sections.content:
Clear, friendly, and confident communication is key to building trust with guests. Use the following approved phrases and scripts as your go-to reference for daily front desk interactions.

📞 Phone Greeting

"Thank you for calling J. Joseph Salon [Location Name], this is [Your Name], how can I assist you today?"

📝 Booking Appointments

  • "I'd be happy to get that scheduled for you."
  • "Would you prefer morning, afternoon, or evening availability?"
  • "Your appointment is confirmed for [day/time] with [stylist name]. Is there anything else I can help with?"

⌛ Running Behind / Delays

  • "We truly appreciate your patience — [stylist name] is finishing up and will be with you shortly."
  • "We're running just a few minutes behind. Can I offer you a beverage while you wait?"

💳 Price & Payment

  • "Let me double-check your total before we check you out."
  • "The final total today is [$XXX]. How would you like to pay?"
  • "Would you like to leave gratuity on card or cash today?"

📦 Product & Retail

  • "Would you like me to show you what [stylist name] used on your hair today?"
  • "We have a promotion going on right now if you're interested."
  • "That product is perfect for [benefit], and we just restocked!"

🤕 Unhappy Guest (Initial Response)

  • "I'm so sorry to hear that — thank you for bringing it to our attention."
  • "Let's talk through what happened so we can make it right."

🎁 Gift Card / Contest

  • "We have gift cards available in any amount — they never expire!"
  • "You've been entered in this month's guest giveaway — we'll reach out if you win!"

📣 When You Don't Know the Answer

  • "Let me double-check that for you."
  • "I want to make sure I give you the right info — give me one moment."

Keep this list nearby and review regularly with your team. Consistency in tone and language builds guest trust and sets the foundation for 5-star service.

sections.title: Handling Stylists No Longer With Us
sections.content:
It's common for guests to call and ask for stylists who have moved on from J. Joseph Salon. Your response should always be professional, neutral, and focused on retention — never personal or emotional.

🗣️ What to Say (Approved Script)

"That stylist is no longer with J. Joseph Salon, but I'd love to help you find a new match based on your preferences. Would you be open to some recommendations?"

📌 Important Tone Guidelines

  • Keep it neutral — no gossip, hints, or details.
  • Avoid phrases like:
    • "She just walked out"
    • "They got fired"
    • "They went to another salon"
  • Focus on what you can do, not what you can't:
    • Offer to match them with another team member
    • Reference notes from their previous visits
    • Suggest stylists at the same level or with similar strengths

📚 Use of Client Notes

  • Review past appointment notes to recommend a stylist with similar:
    • Techniques (e.g. balayage, pixie cuts)
    • Product preferences
    • Communication style

📲 If They Ask for Contact Info

"We don't share team members' personal contact information once they've left the company, but we'd still love to take care of you here."

  • Do not share:
    • Instagram handles
    • Phone numbers
    • Locations they moved to (even if you know)

🧠 Train Your Team

  • All FD team members should rehearse this script
  • Log repeat inquiries in your call notes or guest comments
  • Follow up with the Salon Manager if guests seem frustrated or disengaged

Handled professionally, this is an opportunity to retain the guest and rebuild trust — not lose them.

sections.title: Hurricane Prep Procedure for Front Desk Managers
sections.content:
When a hurricane is expected to impact the area, FD Managers play a key role in preparing the salon for safety, communication, and operational recovery. Follow this checklist immediately after corporate leadership alerts you to begin hurricane prep.

🌪️ Hurricane Preparation Checklist

  1. Confirm with Leadership
    Wait for official notification from the GM or HR to begin storm prep.
  2. Secure Physical Items
    • Move all electronics off the floor
    • Unplug computers, printers, and phones
    • Store all retail displays and signage safely
    • Remove all clutter from the front desk and lobby
  3. Clean & Clear
    • Empty trash and remove perishables from the fridge
    • Remove all items near windows or doorways
    • Wipe down all surfaces
  4. Digital Backups
    Ensure:
    • Guest data is backed up to cloud-based platforms
    • Duty logs, appointment records, and inventory notes are saved
  5. Communicate Closures
    • Post to Slack and update all team members
    • Send end-of-day email confirming what was completed
    • Confirm auto-replies are set up for phones and email (if closing)
  6. FD Manager Office Kit
    Take the following home:
    • Charger
    • Laptop or tablet (if issued)
    • Salon key (if you are on reopening duty)
    • Notebook or paper records (if needed)

📆 Reopening Protocol

Once cleared to reopen:

  • Confirm water and power are functioning before guests arrive
  • Post on Slack to notify the team
  • Re-plug in electronics and recheck all systems
  • Contact the Inventory Manager if any items were damaged or lost

⚠️ Safety First

Do not drive to work or reopen unless officially approved. All storm-related updates will come from corporate leadership — not team Slack chats or texts.

Your role in storm prep ensures both safety and fast recovery. Follow these steps carefully and document everything.

sections.title: Guest Incentives & Gift Card Contest Guidelines
sections.content:
Incentives are a great way to boost guest engagement and reward your FD team for strong performance. As the FD Manager, you're responsible for making sure incentive materials are visible, used properly, and tracked clearly.

🎟️ Guest Incentive Cards

  • Each location has branded guest incentive cards that may offer:
    • % off future visits
    • Product samples or bundles
    • Loyalty stamps
  • Cards should be:
    • Kept stocked and visible at the front desk
    • Only distributed per the current promotion or campaign instructions
    • Logged if tracking is part of the incentive
  • Never hand them out at random — follow the specific usage guidance from your Salon Manager or corporate marketing.

🎁 Gift Card Contest (Annual)

Every holiday season (typically Nov–Dec), FD teams participate in a gift card sales contest.

Rules:

  • Each location is issued a $100 JJS gift card to award the top-selling FD team member.
  • Track all gift card sales from Nov 1 through Dec 31
  • Use the shared tracking spreadsheet or Monday.com to record totals
  • Do not wait until the last minute — update weekly

Announce the Winner:

  • Winner should be announced during your January team meeting
  • Celebrate publicly on Slack or in your internal group chat
  • Winner receives:
    • The $100 gift card
    • Recognition in salon-wide updates

📣 Promote with Confidence

  • Remind guests:
    "We do offer gift cards in any amount — and they never expire!"
  • Keep signage clean, clear, and brand-aligned
  • Ensure retail bundles or promos are clearly explained if part of an incentive

Incentives are more than giveaways — they're a way to thank guests, boost team morale, and increase front desk engagement.
